title: I'm an existential nihilist. Do any other nihilists often get depressed about it? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m afraid you’re not a nihilist then, my friend. What is there to be depressed about? Where existence has no purpose or necessary significance then even ‘depression’ is a non-event. There is no sense in which ‘depression’ is any worse or any better than ‘happiness’ - because all the minuscule mechanisms of quarks and bosons chaotically coinciding to meaninglessly manifest as the illusion of intelligence you call your ‘self’ are absolutely devoid of any implications and thoroughly inconsequential in every sense. They are senseless - there is no importance to any one of their properties or processes - including everything that amounts to the operations of your brain. So, in reality, a depressed nihilist is a contradiction. Depression only exists in contrast to a sense of satisfaction that one considers correct. That means something matters, and that things ought to be a certain way. If a nihilist is actually truthful then they will not be affected by the belief that there is any genuine reason to ascribe value to anything - especially not themselves. In existential nihilism everything is meaninglessly arbitrary, which is exactly why there’s no such thing as a true existential nihilist. ‘Truth’ is not a thing. At least, it is not a thing in any way that applies in any sense. An existential nihilist has no reason to be depressed. An existential nihilist has no reason to be content. An existential nihilist has no reason to be an existential nihilist. An existential nihilist has no reason.  Well, clearly because things matter.
Existential Nihilist tend to get depressed due to the lack of interest in anything.  But hey, just because we are doomed doesn’t mean we shouldn’t have a good time while we are at it.
